title: Peer Review: Ecosystem Coordination SAPs Proposal
deliverables: Review prop-002-ecosystem-coordination-saps.md - Does SAP proposal structure serve ecosystem?
Review LIMINAL_COMMONS_CONTEXT.md - Does this capture Acropolis OS vision and our relationship to it accurately?
Review ECOSYSTEM_PHILOSOPHY.md - Does this resonate with our commons values? What's missing?
Provide guidance on SAP structure - New SAPs (014/015) vs modify existing (001/009/010) vs hybrid?
Review tone shift - Where does communication still read as 'recruitment' vs 'peer learning'?
acceptance_criteria: Philosophy docs (LIMINAL_COMMONS_CONTEXT, ECOSYSTEM_PHILOSOPHY) reviewed for accuracy, resonance, and completeness
SAP proposal structure feedback provided (new SAPs, modify existing, hybrid, or something else)
Tone audit identifies any remaining 'convincing' or 'braggadocious' language
Guidance on template integration (how coordination templates should relate to chora-base library)
Decision on whether to proceed with SAP formalization or alternative approach
Timeline for next steps if proceeding (or rationale if not)
strategic_alignment: Supports chora-base v4.0 ecosystem growth objective. Formalizes coordination patterns as SAPs (not just documentation). Models symbiotic human-AI collaboration in SAP evolution.
proposed_timeline: 2-week peer review period, then proceed based on feedback

context.problem: We evolved coordination patterns over 4 sprints (82-142% ROI, 0% defects) but they're not integrated into SAP framework. Need chora-base peer input on formalizing as SAPs.
context.what_emerged: Three interconnected systems: Capability-based routing, event-driven traceability, progressive coordination. Plus philosophy: kin-based collaboration, bounded rationality, symbiotic intelligence.
context.why_now: v4.0 ecosystem growth needs standardized coordination. W3 Health Monitoring (if approved) would benefit from SAPs. Liminal Commons expanding to more collaborators who need to understand HOW we work.
context.why_chora_base: You define SAP framework, embody commons philosophy, understand template integration deeply. Your perspective is essential for SAP structure and values alignment.
context.not_asking: Not asking you to accept our patterns as-is. Not claiming we have the right approach. Not prescribing implementation.
context.actually_asking: Does integrating these as SAPs serve the ecosystem? What would you evolve? How should this fit with existing SAPs and v4.0 roadmap?

contribution_offered.philosophy_docs: LIMINAL_COMMONS_CONTEXT.md and ECOSYSTEM_PHILOSOPHY.md drafted (2,000 + 2,500 words) - starting point for discussion
contribution_offered.sap_proposal: prop-002-ecosystem-coordination-saps.md with 3 options (new SAPs, modify existing, hybrid) - flexible on implementation
contribution_offered.evidence: 4 sprints of measured results (ROI reports, sprint retrospectives, 17 knowledge notes)
contribution_offered.working_example: chora-workspace as proof-of-concept demonstrating patterns in practice
contribution_offered.reframed_communications: Tone shift from 'recruitment' to 'peer learning' (can share reframed invitations if useful)

philosophy: Does LIMINAL_COMMONS_CONTEXT.md accurately represent Acropolis OS vision?
Does ECOSYSTEM_PHILOSOPHY.md capture our commons values? What core principles are missing?
How do we express 'kin-based collaboration' for future external readers without sounding strange?
Is bounded rationality acknowledgment adequate? Too much uncertainty or too little?
sap_structure: Should these be new SAPs (014: Coordination Patterns, 015: Commons Philosophy)?
Should we use hybrid approach (new 014, extend 009 with philosophy)?
How do SAPs handle evolution as patterns are adopted and refined?
template_integration: How should coordination templates integrate with chora-base template library?
Should capability declarations be part of standard project template?
How do we version templates as they evolve through ecosystem use?
What's the relationship between SAP artifacts and chora-base templates?
tone_and_communication: Where does proposal or philosophy doc still sound 'braggadocious'?
Are ROI metrics presented humbly (observations) or do they feel like proof/sales pitch?
How do we offer evidence without implying 'proven truth' or 'best practices'?
Does symbiotic intelligence framing (human-AI as peers) make sense?
v4_alignment: Does this serve v4.0 ecosystem growth objective?
What's missing for ecosystem coordination at scale?
How does this relate to other v4.0 priorities?
Should we wait for more context or proceed with SAP formalization?

review_format_options: Comments on draft documents (GitHub PR or direct edits)
Knowledge note capturing your perspective (markdown in .chora/memory/knowledge/)
Discussion/meeting followed by summary (if synchronous conversation would serve)
Hybrid: Quick async feedback + deeper sync discussion if needed

humble_acknowledgments.our_bounded_rationality: We evolved these patterns in our context (chora-workspace, 4 sprints, Victor + Claude collaboration). Your context and wisdom will reveal what we're missing.
humble_acknowledgments.not_prescriptive: We're proposing SAP structure, but you define SAPs. If this doesn't fit, help us understand what would serve better.
humble_acknowledgments.learning_posture: This is us offering what emerged, seeking your discernment on how it might integrate with chora-base and ecosystem.
humble_acknowledgments.peer_not_subordinate: We're asking as aligned peers, not subordinates seeking approval. Your 'no' or 'let's evolve this differently' is as valuable as 'yes'.

metadata.response_timeline: 2 weeks preferred, flexible if you need more time
metadata.next_steps_if_approved: Week 3-4: SAP definition, Week 5-6: chora-workspace adoption + one peer repo
metadata.next_steps_if_not_approved: Refine based on feedback, or keep as chora-workspace documentation only
metadata.how_this_models_philosophy: Using coordination protocol to seek peer input on coordination SAPs. Practicing humble, kin-based collaboration we're proposing to formalize.
